content: @WG-async-sprint-planning meeting in 2 minutes
Hello everyone! Leave a :wave: so we know you're here
To start, let's spend time updating the previous sprint section
@triagebot end-topic for when you're ready

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
I'm going to start re-working the RPIT refactor we were doing that would allow RPITIT that would also allow async fns in traits :)
adding that to the list ...
ok, I'll make the upcoming sprint section
I think we can move on to the retro
Sprint retrospective
Thoughts? Feelings? Observations?
so, on the one hand, my review effort paid off
for PR #92508
because the PR author and I identified an outright change in behavior that wasn't going to fly (IMO)
but its also sad
because the PR won't land?
because in the end, the answer was to reduce scope and not try to address that issue
at least, not that way
there is the "but its also great"
because maybe the PR author will attack doing it "the other way" (RFC 66, aka #15023) that works more generally

I'm feeling pretty good about the work that @tmandry and I have been doing towards "dyn async fns". I'm feeling frustrated because it felt like "we're done!" for months now, but I think the latest reduction in scope has let us really flesh out the trickiest part of the design.
In particular, we're just focusing on "returning impl trait and dyn"
and not the full range of improvements we'd like to make
I'm also fairly happy with the explainer structure and so forth that we've evolved

I'm feeling sad because I've not really done any polish work in some time, though @eholk and I have a plan to talk about intersection regions tomorrow (which would unblock that very first issue I tried to address :)
On my initiative, I agree that we've been making good progress. The sprint goals didn't really reflect that, they were a little too ambitious and we didn't actually complete any of them.
I made some progress on stack traces, although I wish I'd prioritized making a concrete proposal more.
I'm also cautiously optimistic that I found the last underlying issue with the generator drop tracking ICEs, and have a fix out for it.
one thing that @tmandry and I have been talking about is that maybe we should turn this "dyn" work into a lang team initiative on its own
I'm also somewhat disappointed that I haven't gotten to the polish work. I don't have time scheduled to do that like I do for the fundamentals work
but also @Yoshua Wuyts [he/they] contexts and capabilities came up in the lang team meeting yesterday
I still want to do another crater run to make sure all the ICEs are actually fixed once these land though.

tmandry said:

I'm also somewhat disappointed that I haven't gotten to the polish work. I don't have time scheduled to do that like I do for the fundamentals work

I think most of the polish issues are larger than can reasonably be done in one sprint, especially if we want to work on any other goals.
@nikomatsakis oh interesting!

tmandry said:

I'm also somewhat disappointed that I haven't gotten to the polish work. I don't have time scheduled to do that like I do for the fundamentals work

its hard to set aside time for it. At least for me, I act like "okay I'll whip this out in 30min" and then every time I'm start, I'm like "wait, I don't understand the behavior I'm seeing at all."

Yoshua Wuyts [he/they] said:

nikomatsakis oh interesting!

...and in particular this RFC for "global extern traits" (a kind of limited-version that is global).
extern types you mean?
no

I got the blog post out with an initial proposal for async::{read. write} which is a big goal, and I'm pretty happy with the proposal in terms of meeting various goals. Would love some feedback from the WG though :-)
generalization of global Allocators and global panic handlers, I think
@eholk @pnkfelix Hm yeah.. maybe the sprint goals should be something like "understand why the behavior is happening and document it in a comment"

...and in particular this RFC for "global extern traits" (a kind of limited-version that is global).

which RFC is that?

tmandry said:

eholk pnkfelix Hm yeah.. maybe the sprint goals should be something like "understand why the behavior is happening and document it in a comment"

That's a good idea. The polish issues I've been able to look into in depth have pretty much all ended up in the "this needs fundamental changes to borrow checking or phasing of compiler passes" category.
@Nick Cameron that's awesome btw, :tada:
I need to read a number of wg related things. This goes back to the earlier conversation about prioritizing review work. Maybe we should document all the reviews we did in each sprint?
I've not read it yet :P
(whether PRs or blog posts or zulip threads..)
that's an interesting idea

Nick Cameron said:

which RFC is that?

...I'm trying to find it, I can't remember the keywords...
https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2492

tmandry said:

(whether PRs or blog posts or zulip threads..)

its especially interesting if it ends up meaning that we get pointed at the important ones that we should all read. :)
RFC: Existential types with external definition rust-lang/rfcs#2492

tmandry said:

I need to read a number of wg related things. This goes back to the earlier conversation about prioritizing review work. Maybe we should document all the reviews we did in each sprint?

I'd want this to be an additional way of seeing for ourselves that we made meaningful contributions, often outside of our specific initiatives
I definitely think doing a review counts as polish work :)
and summarizing the scenario
I did a pernos.co demo for the rustc-reading-club that may be of interest for people working on the compiler
@nikomatsakis I don't mean just PRs though, I'm including reviewing blog posts from other initiatives etc.
ah
that's a good idea

pnkfelix said:

I did a pernos.co demo for the rustc-reading-club that may be of interest for people working on the compiler

with an associated document: https://hackmd.io/_BnRFW1hRfidntrUC4oc7A
but yeah, reviewing PRs counts as polish

pnkfelix said:

I did a pernos.co demo for the rustc-reading-club that may be of interest for people working on the compiler

ah yes I've had the video for this sitting in a tab :) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uTc7KCBbVFI
(brb--afk for a sec)
okay, moving on?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Polish issues for upcoming sprint
Let's start filling this out in the upcoming sprint section
Project board if you need it
Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?
@triagebot end-topic if not

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

tmandry said:

Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?

There are a couple pending fixes for generator drop tracking
I have a quick question
I think I will investigate https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57017 for my polish issue
in particular i believe there are still yet more improvements that are unrelated to drop tracking
I guess I don't know what my question is-- mostly whether @eholk agrees :)
re initiative goals, I have an idea for one but I don't think I can spend time on it myself

nikomatsakis said:

in particular i believe there are still yet more improvements that are unrelated to drop tracking

I definitely agree!
my polish goal is going to be "write out a plan for a next improvement"
not implement :)
@nikomatsakis - if you want help with that I've done a lot of thinking about this

pnkfelix said:

re initiative goals, I have an idea for one but I don't think I can spend time on it myself

specifically: there is interest in taking tokio-console and making it work on other things besides tokio. Specifically, Rayon

eholk said:

tmandry said:

Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?

There are a couple pending fixes for generator drop tracking

I can take a look at one if it would help
we can chat about it a bit, I have a specific case I was interested in
Initiative goals for next sprint
I think we're ready to move on now.. :)

tmandry said:

eholk said:

tmandry said:

Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?

There are a couple pending fixes for generator drop tracking

I can take a look at one if it would help

This one in particular has been sitting for awhile, so that might be a good place to help. Wesley has been looking at it some too, but I think he's busy with a lot of other things.

pnkfelix said:

specifically: there is interest in taking tokio-console and making it work on other things besides tokio. Specifically, Rayon

even more specifically: Eliza already has a branch prototyped. But I think she needs help, from, as she herself put it, someone who understands Rayon
maybe I should tweet or something.
@nikomatsakis where do Rayon people talk?
/me skims streams list
@pnkfelix gitter :)
I've been wanting to move Rayon to zulip for some time
ugh yet another chat client
@Josh Triplett and I had a vague plan around this, the idea of having "sponsored external projects" (at least one rust team member vouches for it)
wow I haven't used gitter in a very long time
just never wrote it up

eholk said:

tmandry said:

eholk said:

tmandry said:

Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?

There are a couple pending fixes for generator drop tracking

I can take a look at one if it would help

This one in particular has been sitting for awhile, so that might be a good place to help. Wesley has been looking at it some too, but I think he's busy with a lot of other things.

If this is something that blocks further progress on drop tracking, a conservative alternative that doesn't affect anything else would be to reduce precision on typeck side to match MIR building, i.e., check only for call expression with never type.
Okay, I added a review of #93313 to my polish goals.

tm said:

eholk said:

tmandry said:

eholk said:

tmandry said:

Are there any PRs up for polish issues needing a review?

There are a couple pending fixes for generator drop tracking

I can take a look at one if it would help

This one in particular has been sitting for awhile, so that might be a good place to help. Wesley has been looking at it some too, but I think he's busy with a lot of other things.

If this is something that blocks further progress on drop tracking, a conservative alternative that doesn't affect anything else would be to reduce precision on typeck side to match MIR building, i.e., check only for call expression with never type.

There's also a fix in the sanity check on the MIR side that's really easy, but given that we have a PR for a more correct fix, I'd rather wait for that one. I have another PR in flight too, so it's not blocking anything yet.
@tmandry what is "constrained impls"
@nikomatsakis also called refined impls.. it's the RFC I've been working on that you reviewed the draft of
I can't decide on a good name
oh, right, ok
do you think @tmandry we can finish off the "returning impl trait via dyn" explainer? one thing to keep in mind is that I'm gone wed-fri next week
though I think we're ... kind of close to done there
oh yeah, and I'm gone monday (it's also a holiday)
but I'd say there's a decent chance we could finish it off in an hour or two
yeah. well, it's a stretch goal :)
I think it's the thing to focus our energy on, regardless
Have to head out, will catch up on scroll-back later
Yeah, I think we should finish it out
I'd also really like to see the RPITIT RFC up again. But let's do this first
agreed, esp. since I think the constrained impls RFC is "teeing things up" for that
yeah
okay, is everyone finished writing these down?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
side note: it seems like no one ever uses :tools:
its for a different style of meeting, maybe
I guess they just say it
i.e. if i'm not done writing things down, should I hit :tools: ?
I was assuming I should just not hit :check:
I think so
i see. so your intent is that it be used to signal that I'm still writing in the hackmd, even if I don'thave anything to say in zulip itself
good to know

nikomatsakis said:

I guess they just say it

I mean saying it is fine, but I think it's there to prevent race conditions while you finish typing :)
(I assume you can understand my confusion here?)
@nikomatsakis Another aspect of vouching for external projects: it's even more obvious if rust-lang/rust depends on the project.
As is the case for rayon.

pnkfelix said:

i see. so your intent is that it be used to signal that I'm still writing in the hackmd, even if I don'thave anything to say in zulip itself

I guess it really depends on whether you're ready to move on, e.g. if you are just finishing up something in the hackmd and it's okay for the conversation to move on in zulip then you don't have to use :tools:
In this case the final thing we do in the meeting is copy/paste all the sprint goals, so it's kind of important to be done before that
(not sure if that's useful for anyone?)
I use it as a chance to read over everyone's goals
its what I do in the T-compiler meeting
transcribe stuff that's already in hackmd, that is.
(breaking things into digestable fragments when needed)
I think its good for driving synchronized review/discussion
yeah, cool
well hopefully the pace works for people
okay, here I go

Async fundamentals

  • [ ] (spastorino) Make RPIT use a type alias to a type defined in body's function
  • [ ] (tmandry) Post constrained impls RFC on the initiative repo
  • [ ] (tmandry) Post constrained impls RFC on the rfcs repo
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis/tmandry) Post first draft of "returning impl Trait in dyn" explainer

Polish

Goals:

  • [ ] (eholk) Write up results from better-backtrace formatting

Issues:

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) Strange async use ...; compiler suggestion #87613
    - [ ] finish extending AST representation
    - previous sprints only added it to ast::Mod; ast::Crate needs it too (!).
    - [ ] add code to identify the injection points
    - [ ] update suggestion machinery

  • [ ] (eholk) Dropped variables still included in generator type [#57478]
    - [ ] Merge fixes for drop tracking ICEs
    - [x] https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/93751
    - [ ] https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/93313
    - [ ] https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/94068
    - [ ] Once fixes merge, do crater run
    - [ ] If crater is okay, change default for -Zdrop-tracking

  • [ ] (eholk/nikomatsakis) Async fn does not compile if lifetime does not appear in bounds (sometimes) [#63033]
    - [ ] Investigate consequences of intersection regions as a way to fix this
  • [ ] (tmandry) Review #93313
  • [ ] (tmandry) E0623 highlights wrong parameter in async fn #74256
    - [ ] Write a note explaining why the suggest_adding_lifetime_params suggestion is not firing on the async cases in the bug
  • [ ] (nikomatsakis) document a plan to improve https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/57017 for one specific case

Interoperability and Portability across runtimes

  • [ ] (nrc) implement vectored Read::read_buf
  • [ ] (nrc) blog post on completion based io and BufRead
  • [ ] (nrc) elaborate on async::{Read, Write} alternatives

Tooling

  • [ ] (pnkfelix) help address "Awaitee field in async fns needs special name" debuginfo blocker for crashdump debugging
/me skims
seems good
One thing I forgot to include was the blog posts from this WG I want to read, but I still think we should include that as progress when we update this sprint in the next meeting
or I want to try it at least
shall we end?
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
On that topic
I have a thought
I've been thinking about how to organize a "traits team" and sone of the things I want to do there is to have not meetings but .. I forget what I called them
"deep dives" I think
sort of like a design meeting
I wonder if a good way to encourage cross-group collaboration woudl be to schedule a rotating monthly deep dive
the structure would be: read a doc
and then talk about it
blog posts could count :)
the whole goal is to spread knowledge
and trigger conversation
it does sound potentially useful/interesting. scheduling is a challenge I'm sure but you could rotate the time slot

nikomatsakis said:

the whole goal is to spread knowledge

In this case you might want to encourage "dumb questions".. I bet for a varied audience a number of people might be lacking important context
We are out of time so I'm going to call the meeting. :wave: thanks everyone!

tmandry said:

In this case you might want to encourage "dumb questions".. I bet for a varied audience a number of people might be lacking important context

yes, the idea for traits was that there is a similar structure of "areas" so to speak, and I'd like to encourage cross-pollination
I wonder if we could use the sprint planning meeting -- e.g., make sprints longer :) and use every other meeting to review? prob a bad idea
I don't really have space in my calendar for more meetings
to be clear, you'd want to use that slot to deep dive on wg-async topics?
I think the cross-pollination would be useful. not sure how people feel about the current sprint pace or how it would be to make them monthly (it feels.. long)
We could use one of the triage meeting slots
